019/**
020 * A text generator for producing sentences and/or words in nonsense languages that fit a theme. This does not use an
021 * existing word list as a basis for its output, so it may or may not produce existing words occasionally, but you can
022 * safely assume it won't generate a meaningful sentence except in the absolute unlikeliest of cases.
023 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 11/29/2015.
024 *
025 * @author Tommy Ettinger
026 */
027
028public class FakeLanguageGen implements Serializable {
029    private static final long serialVersionUID = -2396642435461186352L;
030    public final String[] openingVowels, midVowels, openingConsonants, midConsonants, closingConsonants,
031            vowelSplitters, closingSyllables;
032    public final boolean clean;
033    //public final IntDoubleOrderedMap syllableFrequencies;
034    public final double[] syllableFrequencies;
035    protected double totalSyllableFrequency = 0.0;
036    public final double vowelStartFrequency, vowelEndFrequency, vowelSplitFrequency, syllableEndFrequency;
037    public final Pattern[] sanityChecks;
038    public ArrayList<Modifier> modifiers;
039    public static final GWTRNG srng = new GWTRNG();
040    private static final OrderedMap<String, FakeLanguageGen> registry = new OrderedMap<>(64);
041    protected String summary = null;
042    private String name = "Nameless Language";
043    private static transient StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(20), ender = new StringBuilder(12),
044            ssb = new StringBuilder(80);
045    /**
046     * A pattern String that will match any vowel FakeLanguageGen can produce out-of-the-box, including Latin, Greek,
047     * and Cyrillic; for use when a String will be interpreted as a regex (as in {@link FakeLanguageGen.Alteration}).
048     */
049    public static final String anyVowel = "[àáâãäåæāăąǻǽaèéêëēĕėęěeìíîïĩīĭįıiòóôõöøōŏőœǿoùúûüũūŭůűųuýÿŷỳyαοειυωаеёийоуъыэюя]",
050    /**
051     * A pattern String that will match one or more of any vowels FakeLanguageGen can produce out-of-the-box, including
052     * Latin, Greek, and Cyrillic; for use when a String will be interpreted as a regex (as in 
053     * {@link FakeLanguageGen.Alteration}).
054     */
055    anyVowelCluster = anyVowel + '+',
056    /**
057     * A pattern String that will match any consonant FakeLanguageGen can produce out-of-the-box, including Latin,
058     * Greek, and Cyrillic; for use when a String will be interpreted as a regex (as in
059     * {@link FakeLanguageGen.Alteration}).
060     */
061    anyConsonant = "[bcçćĉċčdþðďđfgĝğġģhĥħjĵȷkķlĺļľŀłmnñńņňŋpqrŕŗřsśŝşšștţťțvwŵẁẃẅxyýÿŷỳzźżžρσζτκχνθμπψβλγφξςбвгдклпрстфхцжмнзчшщ]",
062    /**
063     * A pattern String that will match one or more of any consonants FakeLanguageGen can produce out-of-the-box,
064     * including Latin, Greek, and Cyrillic; for use when a String will be interpreted as a regex (as in
065     * {@link FakeLanguageGen.Alteration}).
066     */
067    anyConsonantCluster = anyConsonant + '+';
068    protected static final Pattern repeats = Pattern.compile("(.)\\1+"),
069            vowelClusters = Pattern.compile(anyVowelCluster, REFlags.IGNORE_CASE | REFlags.UNICODE),
070            consonantClusters = Pattern.compile(anyConsonantCluster, REFlags.IGNORE_CASE | REFlags.UNICODE);

081    static final Pattern[]
082            vulgarChecks = new Pattern[]
083            {
084                    //17 is REFlags.UNICODE | REFlags.IGNORE_CASE
085                    Pattern.compile("[sξζzkкκcсς][hнlι].{1,3}[dtтτΓг]", 17),
086                    Pattern.compile("(?:(?:[pрρ][hн])|[fd]).{1,3}[kкκcсςxхжχq]", 17), // lots of these end in a 'k' sound, huh
087                    Pattern.compile("[kкκcсςСQq][uμυνvhн]{1,3}[kкκcсςxхжχqmм]", 17),
088                    Pattern.compile("[bъыбвβЪЫБ].?[iτιyуλγУ].?[cсς]", 17),
089                    Pattern.compile("[hн][^aаαΛeезξεЗΣiτιyуλγУ][^aаαΛeезξεЗΣiτιyуλγУ]?[rяΓ]", 17),
090                    Pattern.compile("[tтτΓгcсς][iτιyуλγУ][tтτΓг]+$", 17),
091                    Pattern.compile("(?:(?:[pрρ][hн])|f)[aаαΛhн]{1,}[rяΓ][tтτΓг]", 17),
092                    Pattern.compile("[Ssξζzcсς][hн][iτιyуλγУ].?[sξζzcсς]", 17),
093                    Pattern.compile("[aаαΛ][nи][aаαΛeезξεЗΣiτιyуλγУoоюσοuμυνv]{1,2}[Ssξlιζz]", 17),
094                    Pattern.compile("[aаαΛ]([sξζz]{2})", 17),
095                    Pattern.compile("[kкκcсςСQq][hн]?[uμυνv]([hн]?)[nи]+[tтτΓг]", 17),
096                    Pattern.compile("[nиfvν]..?[jg]", 17), // might as well remove two possible slurs and a body part with one check
097                    Pattern.compile("[pрρ](?:(?:([eезξεЗΣoоюσοuμυνv])\\1)|(?:[eезξεЗΣiτιyуλγУuμυνv]+[sξζz]))", 17), // the grab bag of juvenile words
098                    Pattern.compile("[mм][hнwψшщ]?..?[rяΓ].?d", 17), // should pick up the #1 obscenity from Spanish and French
099                    Pattern.compile("[g][hн]?[aаαАΑΛeеёзξεЕЁЗΕΣ][yуλγУeеёзξεЕЁЗΕΣ]", 17), // could be inappropriate for random text
100                    Pattern.compile("[wψшщuμυνv](?:[hн]?)[aаαΛeеёзξεЗΕΣoоюσοuμυνv](?:[nи]+)[gkкκcсςxхжχq]", 17)
101            },
102            genericSanityChecks = new Pattern[]
103                    {
104                            Pattern.compile("[AEIOUaeiou]{3}"),
105                            Pattern.compile("(\\p{L})\\1\\1"),
106                            Pattern.compile("[Ii][iyq]"),
107                            Pattern.compile("[Yy]([aiu])\\1"),
108                            Pattern.compile("[Rr][uy]+[rh]"),
109                            Pattern.compile("[Qq]u[yu]"),
110                            Pattern.compile("[^oaei]uch"),
111                            Pattern.compile("[Hh][tcszi]?h"),
112                            Pattern.compile("[Tt]t[^aeiouy]{2}"),
113                            Pattern.compile("[Yy]h([^aeiouy]|$)"),
114                            Pattern.compile("([xqy])\\1$"),
115                            Pattern.compile("[qi]y$"),
116                            Pattern.compile("[szSZrlRL]+?[^aeiouytdfgkcpbmnslrv][rlsz]"),
117                            Pattern.compile("[UIuiYy][wy]"),
118                            Pattern.compile("^[UIui]e"),
119                            Pattern.compile("^([^aeioyl])\\1", 17)
120                    },
121            englishSanityChecks = new Pattern[]
122                    {
123                            Pattern.compile("[AEIOUaeiou]{3}"),
124                            Pattern.compile("(\\w)\\1\\1"),

127                            Pattern.compile("[Uu][umlkj]"),
128                            Pattern.compile("[Ii][iyqkhrl]"),
129                            Pattern.compile("[Oo][c]"),
130                            Pattern.compile("[Yy]([aiu])\\1"),
131                            Pattern.compile("[Rr][aeiouy]+[rh]"),
132                            Pattern.compile("[Qq]u[yu]"),
133                            Pattern.compile("[^oaei]uch"),
134                            Pattern.compile("[Hh][tcszi]?h"),
135                            Pattern.compile("[Tt]t[^aeiouy]{2}"),
136                            Pattern.compile("[Yy]h([^aeiouy]|$)"),
137                            Pattern.compile("[szSZrlRL]+?[^aeiouytdfgkcpbmnslr][rlsz]"),
138                            Pattern.compile("[UIuiYy][wy]"),
139                            Pattern.compile("^[UIui][ae]"),
140                            Pattern.compile("q(?:u?)$")
141                    },
142            japaneseSanityChecks = new Pattern[]
143                    {

403    /*
404     * Removes accented characters from a string; if the "base" characters are non-English anyway then the result won't
405     * be an ASCII string, but otherwise it probably will be.
406     * <br>
407     * Credit to user hashable from http://stackoverflow.com/a/1215117
408     *
409     * @param str a string that may contain accented characters
410     * @return a string with all accented characters replaced with their (possibly ASCII) counterparts
411     *
412    public String removeAccents(String str) {
413        String alteredString = Normalizer.normalize(str, Normalizer.Form.NFD);
414        alteredString = diacritics.matcher(alteredString).replaceAll("");
415        alteredString = alteredString.replace('æ', 'a');
416        alteredString = alteredString.replace('œ', 'o');
417        alteredString = alteredString.replace('Æ', 'A');
418        alteredString = alteredString.replace('Œ', 'O');
419        return alteredString;
420    }*/
421
422    /**
423     * Removes accented Latin-script characters from a string; if the "base" characters are non-English anyway then the
424     * result won't be an ASCII string, but otherwise it probably will be.
425     *
426     * @param str a string that may contain accented Latin-script characters
427     * @return a string with all accented characters replaced with their (possibly ASCII) counterparts
428     */
429    public static CharSequence removeAccents(CharSequence str) {
430        CharSequence alteredString = str;
431        for (int i = 0; i < accentFinders.length; i++) {
432            alteredString = accentFinders[i].replace(alteredString);
433        }
434        return alteredString;
435    }
436
437    private FakeLanguageGen register(String languageName) {
438        summary = registry.size() + "@1";
439        registry.put(languageName,this);
440        name = languageName;
441        return copy();
442    }
443
444    private FakeLanguageGen summarize(String brief) {
445        summary = brief;
446        return this;
447    }

792    /**
793     * Swahili is one of the more commonly-spoken languages in sub-Saharan Africa, and serves mainly as a shared language
794     * that is often learned after becoming fluent in one of many other (vaguely-similar) languages of the area. An
795     * example sentence in Swahili, that this might try to imitate aesthetically, is "Mtoto mdogo amekisoma," meaning
796     * "The small child reads it" (where it is a book). A notable language feature used here is the redoubling of words,
797     * which is used in Swahili to emphasize or alter the meaning of the doubled word; here, it always repeats exactly
798     * and can't make minor changes like a real language might. This generates things like "gata-gata", "hapi-hapi", and
799     * "mimamzu-mimamzu", always separating with a hyphen here.
800     * <br>
801     * As an aside, please try to avoid the ugly stereotypes that fantasy media often assigns to speakers of African-like
802     * languages when using this or any of the generators. Many fantasy tropes come from older literature written with
803     * major cultural biases, and real-world cultural elements can be much more interesting to players than yet another
804     * depiction of a "jungle savage" with stereotypical traits. Consider drawing from existing lists of real-world
805     * technological discoveries, like https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_science_and_technology_in_Africa , for
806     * inspiration when world-building; though some groups may not have developed agriculture by early medieval times,
807     * their neighbors may be working iron and studying astronomy just a short distance away.
808     * <br>
809     * Kondueyu; ma mpiyamdabota mise-mise nizakwaja alamsa amja, homa nkajupomba.
810     */
811    public static final FakeLanguageGen SWAHILI = swahili().register("Swahili");

853     * Imitation Somali, using the Latin alphabet. Due to uncommon word structure, unusual allowed combinations of
854     * letters, and no common word roots with most familiar languages, this may seem like an unidentifiable or "alien"
855     * language to most readers. However, it's based on the Latin writing system for the Somali language (probably
856     * closest to the northern dialect), which due to the previously mentioned properties, makes it especially good for
857     * mixing with other languages to make letter combinations that seem strange to appear. It is unlikely that this
858     * particular generated language style will be familiar to readers, so it probably won't have existing stereotypes
859     * associated with the text. One early comment this received was, "it looks like a bunch of letters semi-randomly
860     * thrown together", which is probably a typical response (the comment was made by someone fluent in German and
861     * English, and most Western European languages are about as far as you can get from Somali).
862     * <br>
863     * Libor cat naqoxekh dhuugad gisiqir?
864     */
865    public static final FakeLanguageGen SOMALI = somali().register("Somali");

1222    /**
1223     * Imitation Hindi, romanized to use the Latin alphabet using accented glyphs similar to the IAST standard.
1224     * Most fonts do not support the glyphs that IAST-standard romanization of Hindi needs, so this uses alternate
1225     * glyphs from at most Latin Extended-A. Relative to the IAST standard, the glyphs {@code "ṛṝḷḹḍṭṅṇṣṃḥ"} become
1226     * {@code "ŗŕļĺđţńņşĕĭ"}, with the nth glyph in the first string being substituted with the nth glyph in the second
1227     * string. You may want to get a variant on this language with {@link #removeAccents()} if you can't display the
1228     * less-commonly-supported glyphs {@code āīūĕĭáíúóŗŕļţĺđńñņśş}. For some time SquidLib had a separate version of
1229     * imitation Hindi that was accurate to the IAST standard, but this version is more usable because font support is
1230     * much better for the glyphs it uses, so the IAST kind was removed (it added quite a bit of code for something that
1231     * was mostly unusable).
1232     * <br>
1233     * Darvāga yar; ghađhinopŕauka āĕrdur, conśaigaijo śabhodhaĕđū jiviđaudu.
1234     */
1235    public static final FakeLanguageGen HINDI_ROMANIZED = hindi().register("Hindi Romanized");

1276    /**
1277     * Imitation Arabic, using mostly the Latin alphabet but with some Greek letters for tough transliteration topics.
1278     * It's hard to think of a more different (widely-spoken) language to romanize than Arabic. Written Arabic does not
1279     * ordinarily use vowels (the writing system is called an abjad, in contrast to an alphabet), and it has more than a
1280     * few sounds that are very different from those in English. This version, because of limited support in fonts and
1281     * the need for separate words to be distinguishable with regular expressions, uses somewhat-accurate digraphs or
1282     * trigraphs instead of the many accented glyphs (not necessarily supported by most fonts) in most romanizations of
1283     * Arabic, and this scheme uses no characters from outside ASCII.
1284     * <br>
1285     * Please try to be culturally-sensitive about how you use this generator. Classical Arabic (the variant that
1286     * normally marks vowels explicitly and is used to write the Qur'an) has deep religious significance in Islam, and
1287     * if you machine-generate text that (probably) isn't valid Arabic, but claim that it is real, or that it has
1288     * meaning when it actually doesn't, that would be an improper usage of what this generator is meant to do. In a
1289     * fantasy setting, you can easily confirm that the language is fictional and any overlap is coincidental; an
1290     * example of imitation Arabic in use is the Dungeons and Dragons setting, Al-Qadim, which according to one account
1291     * sounds similar to a word in real Arabic (that does not mean anything like what the designer was aiming for). In a
1292     * historical setting, FakeLanguageGen is probably "too fake" to make a viable imitation for any language, and may
1293     * just sound insulting if portrayed as realistic. You may want to mix ARABIC_ROMANIZED with a very different kind
1294     * of language, like GREEK_ROMANIZED or RUSSIAN_AUTHENTIC, to emphasize that this is not a real-world language.
1295     * <br>
1296     * Hiijakki al-aafusiib rihit, ibn-ullukh aj shwisari!
1297     */
1298    public static final FakeLanguageGen ARABIC_ROMANIZED = arabic().register("Arabic Romanized");

1419    /**
1420     * Somewhat close to Old Norse, which is itself very close to Icelandic, so this uses Icelandic spelling rules. Not
1421     * to be confused with the language(s) of Norway, where the Norwegian languages are called norsk, and are further
1422     * distinguished into Bokmål and Nynorsk. This should not be likely to seem like any form of Norwegian, since it
1423     * doesn't have the a-with-ring letter 'å' and has the letters eth ('Ðð') and thorn ('Þþ'). If you want to remove
1424     * any letters not present on a US-ASCII keyboard, you can use {@link Modifier#SIMPLIFY_NORSE} on this language or
1425     * some mix of this with other languages; it also changes some of the usage of "j" where it means the English "y"
1426     * sound, making "fjord" into "fyord", which is closer to familiar uses from East Asia like "Tokyo" and "Pyongyang".
1427     * You can also now use {@link #NORSE_SIMPLIFIED} directly, which is probably easiest.
1428     * <br>
1429     * Leyrk tjör stomri kna snó æd ðrépdápá, prygso?
1430     */
1431    public static final FakeLanguageGen NORSE = norse().register("Norse");

1484     * Mongolian, which was written for many years in the Cyrillic alphabet (same alphabet as Russian) and has changed a
1485     * lot in other ways.
1486     * <br>
1487     * Ghamgarg zilijuub lirgh arghar zunghichuh naboogh.
1488     */
1489    public static final FakeLanguageGen MONGOLIAN = mongolian().register("Mongolian");

1700    /**
1701     * Fantasy language that might be suitable for a language spoken by fiends, users of witchcraft, or people who seek
1702     * to emulate or worship similar groups. The tendency here is for DEMONIC to be the language used by creatures that
1703     * are considered evil because of their violence, while INFERNAL is the language used by creatures that are
1704     * considered evil because of their manipulation and deceit (DEMONIC being "chaotic evil" and INFERNAL being "lawful
1705     * evil"). The name INFERNAL refers to Dante's Inferno and the various naming conventions used for residents of Hell
1706     * in the more-modern Christian traditions (as well as some of the stylistic conventions of Old Testament figures
1707     * described as false idols, such as Moloch and Mammon). In an effort to make this distinct from the general style
1708     * of names used in ancient Hebrew (since this is specifically meant for the names of villains as opposed to normal
1709     * humans), we add in vowel splits as used in LOVECRAFT and DEMONIC, then add quite a few accented vowels. These
1710     * traits make the language especially well-suited for "deal with the Devil" written bargains, where a single accent
1711     * placed incorrectly could change the meaning of a contract and provide a way for a fiend to gain leverage.
1712     * <br>
1713     * Zézîzûth eke'iez áhìphon; úhiah îbbëphéh haîtemheû esmez...
1714     */
1715    public static final FakeLanguageGen INFERNAL = infernal().register("Infernal");

1878    /**
1879     * Imitation text from an approximation of Korean, using the Revised Romanization method that is official in South
1880     * Korea today and is easier to type. The text this makes may be hard to pronounce. Korean is interesting as a
1881     * language to imitate for a number of reasons; many of the sounds in it are rarely found elsewhere, it can cluster
1882     * consonants rather tightly (most languages don't; English does to a similar degree but Japanese hardly has any
1883     * groups of consonants), and there are many more vowel sounds without using tones (here, two or three letters are
1884     * used for a vowel, where the first can be y or w and the rest can be a, e, i, o, or u in some combination). Some
1885     * letter combinations possible here are impossible or very rare in correctly-Romanized actual Korean, such as the
1886     * rare occurrence of a single 'l' before a vowel (it normally only appears in Romanized text before a consonant or
1887     * at the end of a word).
1888     * <br>
1889     * Hyeop euryam, sonyon muk tyeok aengyankeon, koelgwaelmwak.
1890     */
1891    public static final FakeLanguageGen KOREAN_ROMANIZED = korean().register("Korean Romanized");

2060    /**

2062     * an alien species. This alien language emphasizes large clusters of vowels, typically with 2 or 3 vowel sounds
2063     * between consonants, though some vowel groups could be interpreted in multiple ways (such as English "maim" and
2064     * "bail", which also have regional differences in pronunciation). As the name would suggest, it strongly prefers
2065     * using the vowel "o", with it present in about half the groups, but doesn't have any preference toward or against
2066     * the other vowels it uses, "a", "e", "i", and "u". The consonants completely avoid hard sounds like "t" and "k",
2067     * medium-hard sounds like "g" and "b", and also sibilants like "s" and "z".  This should be fairly hard to
2068     * pronounce, but possible.
2069     * <br>
2070     * Foiuhoeorfeaorm novruol naionouffeu meuif; hmoieloreo naemriou.
2071     */

2108    /**
2109     * Fantasy/sci-fi language that could be spoken by some very-non-human culture that would typically be fitting for
2110     * an alien species. This alien language is meant to have an abrupt change mid-word for many words, with the suffix
2111     * of roughly half of words using the letter "e", which is absent from the rest of the language; these suffixes can
2112     * also use consonant clusters, which are similarly absent elsewhere. The suffixes would make sense as a historical
2113     * relic or as a linguistic holdout from a historical merger. As the name would suggest, it strongly prefers
2114     * using the vowel "u", with it present in about half the groups, and can use the umlaut accent "ü" on some vowels.
2115     * The consonants completely avoid hard sounds like "t" and "k", and don't cluster; they often have special marks.
2116     * This should be relatively easy to pronounce for an alien language, though the words are rather long.
2117     * <br>
2118     * Üweħid vuŕeħid deẃul leŋul waloyeyür; äyovavü...
2119     */
2120    public static final FakeLanguageGen ALIEN_U = alien_u().register("Alien U");

2200    /**
2201     * Fantasy language that tries to sound like the speech of a powerful and pompous dragon, using long, complex words
2202     * and a mix of hard consonants like "t" and "k", "liquid" consonants like "l" and "r", and sometimes vowel groups
2203     * like "ie" and "aa". It frequently uses consonant clusters involving "r". It uses no accented characters.
2204     * <br>
2205     * Vokegodzaaz kigrofreth ariatarkioth etrokagik deantoznik hragriemitaaz gianehaadaz...
2206     */

2209    /**
2210     * Fantasy language based closely on {@link #DRAGON}, but with much shorter words normally and closing syllables
2211     * that may sound "rushed" or "crude", though it has the same general frequency of most consonants and vowels.
2212     * This means it still uses lots of "t", "k", and "r", can group two vowels sometimes, and when there's a consonant
2213     * in the middle of a word, it is often accompanied by an "r" on one or both sides. If used with
2214     * {@link NaturalLanguageCipher}, this will look very similar to DRAGON, because the syllable lengths aren't
2215     * determined by this object but by the text being ciphered. Still, the ends of words are often different. It is
2216     * called KOBOLD because, even though the original kobold myth was that of a goblin-like spirit that haunted cobalt
2217     * mines, the modern RPG treatment of kobolds frequently describes them as worshippers of dragons or in some way
2218     * created by dragons, but generally they're a sort of failure to live up to a dragon's high expectations. The feel
2219     * of this language is meant to be something like a dragon's speech, but much less "fancy" and rather curt.
2220     * <br>
2221     * Thritriz, laazak gruz kokak thon lut...
2222     */
2223    public static final FakeLanguageGen KOBOLD = new FakeLanguageGen(
2224            DRAGON.openingVowels, DRAGON.midVowels, DRAGON.openingConsonants, DRAGON.midConsonants, DRAGON.closingConsonants,
2225            new String[]{"ik", "ak", "ek", "at", "it", "ik", "ak", "ek", "at", "it", "ik", "ak", "ek", "at", "it", "et", "ut", "ark", "irk", "erk"},
2226            DRAGON.vowelSplitters, new int[]{1, 2, 3}, new double[]{5, 11, 1},
2227            0.1, 0.0, 0.0, 0.22, genericSanityChecks, true).register("Kobold");

2262    /**
2263     * Fantasy/sci-fi language that would typically be fitting for an insect-like species without a close equivalent to
2264     * human lips. This language emphasizes hard sounds such as 't' and 'k', uses some sibilants such as 's', 'sh', and
2265     * 'x', uses lots of 'r' sounds, includes trill sounds using 'rr' (as in Spanish), and uses primarily 'a' and 'i'

2268     * <br>
2269     * Ritars tsarraxgits, krit trir istsak!
2270     */
2271    public static final FakeLanguageGen INSECT = insect().register("Insect");

2431    /**
2432     * Fantasy/sci-fi language that would potentially be fitting for a trade language spoken by various very-different
2433     * groups, such as creatures with tentacled faces who need to communicate with spider-elves and living crystals.
2434     * This language tries to use relatively few sounds so vocally-restricted species can speak it or approximate it,
2435     * but some of its sounds are uncommon. It uses "ng" as Vietnamese does, as a sound that can be approximated with
2436     * "w" but more accurately is like the sound at the end of "gong". It uses a breathy sound in many vowels,
2437     * represented by "h", and this is separate from (and can be combined with) lengthening the vowel by doubling it
2438     * ("a", "ah", "aa", and "aah" are different). The "x" sound can be approximated by any of the "kh" or "q" sounds
2439     * used in various human languages, or with its usage in English for "ks". This does separate some vowels with "'",
2440     * which can be a glottal stop as in Hawaiian or various other languages, or approximated with a brief pause.
2441     * <br>
2442     * Zrolmolurz, voluu, nguu yuh'ongohng!
2443     */
2444    public static final FakeLanguageGen DEEP_SPEECH = deepSpeech().register("Deep Speech");
2445    /**
2446     * Somewhat close to Old Norse, which is itself very close to Icelandic, but changed to avoid letters not on a
2447     * US-ASCII keyboard. Not to be confused with the language(s) of Norway, where the Norwegian languages are called
2448     * norsk, and are further distinguished into Bokmål and Nynorsk. This just applies {@link Modifier#SIMPLIFY_NORSE}
2449     * to {@link #NORSE}. This replaces eth ('Ðð') and thorn ('Þþ') with 'th' unless preceded by 's' (where 'sð' or 'sþ'
2450     * becomes "st") or followed by 'r' (where 'ðr' or 'þr' becomes 'fr'). It replaces 'Æ' or 'æ' with 'Ae' or 'ae', and
2451     * replaces 'Ö' or 'ö' with 'Ou' or "ou", which can change the length of a String relative to NORSE. It removes all
2452     * other accent marks (since the two-dot umlaut accent has already been changed, this only affects acute accents).
2453     * It also changes some of the usage of "j" where it means the English "y" sound, making "fjord" into "fyord", which
2454     * is closer to familiar uses from East Asia like "Tokyo" and "Pyongyang".
2455     * <br>
2456     * Leyrk tyour stomri kna sno aed frepdapa, prygso?
2457     */
2458    public static final FakeLanguageGen NORSE_SIMPLIFIED = norse().addModifiers(Modifier.SIMPLIFY_NORSE)
2459            .register("Norse Simplified");

2614    /**
2615     * A rough imitation of the Crow language of the American Midwest, using some tone marks. Some of the orthography
2616     * rules aren't clear across Internet information about the language, so this really is a "fake" language it will be
2617     * generating, not the real thing at all. This considers 'x' to be the rough back-of-throat noise that isn't in
2618     * English other than in loanwords, like the Scottish "loch," and in names like the German "Bach." Doubled (to use
2619     * the linguistic term, geminated) consonants are pronounced for a longer time, and doubled vowels with the same
2620     * accent mark or no accent mark are also lengthened. An un-accented vowel has a normal tone, an accented vowel has
2621     * a high tone, and an accented vowel followed by an un-accented vowel has a falling tone. This last feature is the
2622     * least common among languages here, and is a good way of distinguishing imitation Crow from other languages.
2623     * <br>
2624     * Pashu-umíkiki; chinébúlu ak kóokutú shu-eníí-a ipíimúu heekokáakoku?
2625     */
2626    public static final FakeLanguageGen CROW = crow().register("Crow");

2784    /**
2785     * Fantasy language that is meant to sound like it could be spoken by divine or (magical) otherworldly beings.
2786     * Sometimes uses the breve mark (as in {@code ăĕĭŏ}) over vowels and rarely splits consonants with {@code '}.
2787     * Uses very few harsh sounds, and may be easy to confuse with {@link #ELF} (this tends to use much shorter words).
2788     * This happens to sound a little like Hebrew, but since this doesn't have some consonants that are commonly used in
2789     * Hebrew, and because this uses accented vowels that aren't in Hebrew, they should be different enough that this
2790     * language can seem "not of this world."
2791     * <br>
2792     * Emŏl ebin hanzi'ab, isharar omrihrel nevyăd.
2793     */

2796    /**
2797     * An array that stores all the hand-made FakeLanguageGen constants; it does not store randomly-generated languages
2798     * nor does it store modifications or mixes of languages. The order these are stored in is related to the numeric
2799     * codes for languages in the {@link #serializeToString()} output, but neither is dependent on the other if this
2800     * array is changed for some reason (which is not recommended, but not out of the question). If this is modified,
2801     * then it is probably a bad idea to assign null to any elements in registered; special care is taken to avoid null
2802     * elements in its original state, so some code may rely on the items being usable and non-null.
2803     */
2804    public static final FakeLanguageGen[] registered;
2805    public static final String[] registeredNames;
2806    static {
2807        // the first item in registry is null so it can be a placeholder for random languages; we want to skip it.
2808        registered = new FakeLanguageGen[registry.size()-1];
2809        registeredNames = new String[registered.length];
2810        for (int i = 0; i < registered.length; i++) {
2811            registeredNames[i] = registry.keyAt(i+1);
2812            registered[i] = registry.getAt(i+1);
2813        }
2814    }
2815
2816    /**
2817     * If a FakeLanguageGen is known and is in {@link #registered}, this allows you to look up that FakeLanguageGen by
2818     * name (using a name from {@link #registeredNames}).
2819     * @param name a String name such as "English", "Korean Romanized", or "Russian Authentic"
2820     * @return a FakeLanguageGen corresponding to the given name, or null if none was found
2821     */
2822    public static FakeLanguageGen get(String name)
2823    {
2824        return registry.get(name);
2825    }
2826    /**
2827     * If a FakeLanguageGen is known and is in {@link #registered}, this allows you to look up that FakeLanguageGen by
2828     * index, from 0 to {@code FakeLanguageGen.registered.length - 1}.
2829     * @param index an int from 0 to {@code FakeLanguageGen.registered.length - 1}
2830     * @return a FakeLanguageGen corresponding to the given index, or null if none was found
2831     */
2832    public static FakeLanguageGen getAt(int index)
2833    {
2834        return registry.getAt(index);
2835    }
2836    /**
2837     * If a FakeLanguageGen is known and is in {@link #registered}, this allows you to look up that FakeLanguageGen's
2838     * name by index, from 0 to {@code FakeLanguageGen.registeredNames.length - 1}.
2839     * @param index an int from 0 to {@code FakeLanguageGen.registeredNames.length - 1}
2840     * @return a FakeLanguageGen corresponding to the given index, or null if none was found
2841     */
2842    public static String nameAt(int index)
2843    {
2844        return registry.keyAt(index);
2845    }

2904    /**
2905     * This is a very complicated constructor! Maybe look at the calls to this to initialize static members of this
2906     * class, LOVECRAFT and GREEK_ROMANIZED.
2907     *
2908     * @param openingVowels        String array where each element is a vowel or group of vowels that may appear at the start
2909     *                             of a word or in the middle; elements may be repeated to make them more common
2910     * @param midVowels            String array where each element is a vowel or group of vowels that may appear in the
2911     *                             middle of the word; all openingVowels are automatically copied into this internally.
2912     *                             Elements may be repeated to make them more common
2913     * @param openingConsonants    String array where each element is a consonant or consonant cluster that can appear
2914     *                             at the start of a word; elements may be repeated to make them more common
2915     * @param midConsonants        String array where each element is a consonant or consonant cluster than can appear
2916     *                             between vowels; all closingConsonants are automatically copied into this internally.
2917     *                             Elements may be repeated to make them more common
2918     * @param closingConsonants    String array where each element is a consonant or consonant cluster than can appear
2919     *                             at the end of a word; elements may be repeated to make them more common
2920     * @param closingSyllables     String array where each element is a syllable starting with a vowel and ending in
2921     *                             whatever the word should end in; elements may be repeated to make them more common
2922     * @param vowelSplitters       String array where each element is a mark that goes between vowels, so if "-" is in this,
2923     *                             then "a-a" may be possible; elements may be repeated to make them more common
2924     * @param syllableLengths      int array where each element is a possible number of syllables a word can use; closely
2925     *                             tied to syllableFrequencies
2926     * @param syllableFrequencies  double array where each element corresponds to an element in syllableLengths and
2927     *                             represents how often each syllable count should appear relative to other counts; there
2928     *                             is no need to restrict the numbers to add up to any other number
2929     * @param vowelStartFrequency  a double between 0.0 and 1.0 that determines how often words start with vowels;
2930     *                             higher numbers yield more words starting with vowels
2931     * @param vowelEndFrequency    a double between 0.0 and 1.0 that determines how often words end with vowels; higher
2932     *                             numbers yield more words ending in vowels
2933     * @param vowelSplitFrequency  a double between 0.0 and 1.0 that, if vowelSplitters is not empty, determines how
2934     *                             often a vowel will be split into two vowels separated by one of those splitters
2935     * @param syllableEndFrequency a double between 0.0 and 1.0 that determines how often an element of
2936     *                             closingSyllables is used instead of ending normally
2937     */
2938    public FakeLanguageGen(String[] openingVowels, String[] midVowels, String[] openingConsonants,
2939                           String[] midConsonants, String[] closingConsonants, String[] closingSyllables, String[] vowelSplitters,
2940                           int[] syllableLengths, double[] syllableFrequencies, double vowelStartFrequency,
2941                           double vowelEndFrequency, double vowelSplitFrequency, double syllableEndFrequency) {
2942        this(openingVowels, midVowels, openingConsonants, midConsonants, closingConsonants, closingSyllables,
2943                vowelSplitters, syllableLengths, syllableFrequencies, vowelStartFrequency, vowelEndFrequency,
2944                vowelSplitFrequency, syllableEndFrequency, englishSanityChecks, true);
2945    }

2947    /**
2948     * This is a very complicated constructor! Maybe look at the calls to this to initialize static members of this
2949     * class, LOVECRAFT and GREEK_ROMANIZED.
2950     *
2951     * @param openingVowels        String array where each element is a vowel or group of vowels that may appear at the start
2952     *                             of a word or in the middle; elements may be repeated to make them more common
2953     * @param midVowels            String array where each element is a vowel or group of vowels that may appear in the
2954     *                             middle of the word; all openingVowels are automatically copied into this internally.
2955     *                             Elements may be repeated to make them more common
2956     * @param openingConsonants    String array where each element is a consonant or consonant cluster that can appear
2957     *                             at the start of a word; elements may be repeated to make them more common
2958     * @param midConsonants        String array where each element is a consonant or consonant cluster than can appear
2959     *                             between vowels; all closingConsonants are automatically copied into this internally.
2960     *                             Elements may be repeated to make them more common
2961     * @param closingConsonants    String array where each element is a consonant or consonant cluster than can appear
2962     *                             at the end of a word; elements may be repeated to make them more common
2963     * @param closingSyllables     String array where each element is a syllable starting with a vowel and ending in
2964     *                             whatever the word should end in; elements may be repeated to make them more common
2965     * @param vowelSplitters       String array where each element is a mark that goes between vowels, so if "-" is in this,
2966     *                             then "a-a" may be possible; elements may be repeated to make them more common
2967     * @param syllableLengths      int array where each element is a possible number of syllables a word can use; closely
2968     *                             tied to syllableFrequencies
2969     * @param syllableFrequencies  double array where each element corresponds to an element in syllableLengths and
2970     *                             represents how often each syllable count should appear relative to other counts; there
2971     *                             is no need to restrict the numbers to add up to any other number
2972     * @param vowelStartFrequency  a double between 0.0 and 1.0 that determines how often words start with vowels;
2973     *                             higher numbers yield more words starting with vowels
2974     * @param vowelEndFrequency    a double between 0.0 and 1.0 that determines how often words end with vowels; higher
2975     *                             numbers yield more words ending in vowels
2976     * @param vowelSplitFrequency  a double between 0.0 and 1.0 that, if vowelSplitters is not empty, determines how
2977     *                             often a vowel will be split into two vowels separated by one of those splitters
2978     * @param syllableEndFrequency a double between 0.0 and 1.0 that determines how often an element of
2979     *                             closingSyllables is used instead of ending normally
2980     * @param sane                 true to perform sanity checks for pronounce-able sounds to most English speakers, replacing many
2981     *                             words that are impossible to say; slows down generation slightly, irrelevant for non-Latin alphabets
2982     * @param clean                true to perform vulgarity/obscenity checks on the word, replacing it if it is too close to a
2983     *                             common English vulgarity, obscenity, or slur/epithet; slows down generation slightly
2984     */
2985    public FakeLanguageGen(String[] openingVowels, String[] midVowels, String[] openingConsonants,
2986                           String[] midConsonants, String[] closingConsonants, String[] closingSyllables, String[] vowelSplitters,
2987                           int[] syllableLengths, double[] syllableFrequencies, double vowelStartFrequency,
2988                           double vowelEndFrequency, double vowelSplitFrequency, double syllableEndFrequency,
2989                           Pattern[] sane, boolean clean) {
2990        this.openingVowels = openingVowels;
2991        this.midVowels = new String[openingVowels.length + midVowels.length];
2992        System.arraycopy(midVowels, 0, this.midVowels, 0, midVowels.length);
2993        System.arraycopy(openingVowels, 0, this.midVowels, midVowels.length, openingVowels.length);
2994        this.openingConsonants = openingConsonants;
2995        this.midConsonants = new String[midConsonants.length + closingConsonants.length];
2996        System.arraycopy(midConsonants, 0, this.midConsonants, 0, midConsonants.length);
2997        System.arraycopy(closingConsonants, 0, this.midConsonants, midConsonants.length, closingConsonants.length);
2998        this.closingConsonants = closingConsonants;
2999        this.vowelSplitters = vowelSplitters;
3000        this.closingSyllables = closingSyllables;
3001
3002        this.syllableFrequencies = new double[syllableLengths[syllableLengths.length - 1]];
3003        totalSyllableFrequency = 0.0;
3004        for (int i = 0; i < syllableLengths.length; i++) {
3005            totalSyllableFrequency += (this.syllableFrequencies[syllableLengths[i]-1] = syllableFrequencies[i]);
3006        }
3007
3008        if (vowelStartFrequency > 1.0)
3009            this.vowelStartFrequency = 1.0 / vowelStartFrequency;
3010        else
3011            this.vowelStartFrequency = vowelStartFrequency;
3012        if (vowelEndFrequency > 1.0)
3013            this.vowelEndFrequency = 1.0 / vowelEndFrequency;
3014        else
3015            this.vowelEndFrequency = vowelEndFrequency;
3016        if (vowelSplitters.length == 0)
3017            this.vowelSplitFrequency = 0.0;
3018        else if (vowelSplitFrequency > 1.0)
3019            this.vowelSplitFrequency = 1.0 / vowelSplitFrequency;
3020        else
3021            this.vowelSplitFrequency = vowelSplitFrequency;
3022        if (closingSyllables.length == 0)
3023            this.syllableEndFrequency = 0.0;
3024        else if (syllableEndFrequency > 1.0)
3025            this.syllableEndFrequency = 1.0 / syllableEndFrequency;
3026        else
3027            this.syllableEndFrequency = syllableEndFrequency;
3028        this.clean = clean;
3029        sanityChecks = sane;
3030        modifiers = new ArrayList<>(4);
3031    }
3032
3033    private FakeLanguageGen(String[] openingVowels, String[] midVowels, String[] openingConsonants,
3034                            String[] midConsonants, String[] closingConsonants, String[] closingSyllables,
3035                            String[] vowelSplitters, double[] syllableFrequencies,
3036                            double vowelStartFrequency, double vowelEndFrequency, double vowelSplitFrequency,
3037                            double syllableEndFrequency, Pattern[] sanityChecks, boolean clean,
3038                            List<Modifier> modifiers) {
3039        this.openingVowels = copyStrings(openingVowels);
3040        this.midVowels = copyStrings(midVowels);
3041        this.openingConsonants = copyStrings(openingConsonants);
3042        this.midConsonants = copyStrings(midConsonants);
3043        this.closingConsonants = copyStrings(closingConsonants);
3044        this.closingSyllables = copyStrings(closingSyllables);
3045        this.vowelSplitters = copyStrings(vowelSplitters);
3046        this.syllableFrequencies = Arrays.copyOf(syllableFrequencies, syllableFrequencies.length);
3047        this.vowelStartFrequency = vowelStartFrequency;
3048        this.vowelEndFrequency = vowelEndFrequency;
3049        this.vowelSplitFrequency = vowelSplitFrequency;
3050        this.syllableEndFrequency = syllableEndFrequency;
3051        for (int i = 0; i < syllableFrequencies.length; i++) {
3052            totalSyllableFrequency += syllableFrequencies[i];
3053        }
3054        if (sanityChecks == null)
3055            this.sanityChecks = null;
3056        else {
3057            this.sanityChecks = new Pattern[sanityChecks.length];
3058            System.arraycopy(sanityChecks, 0, this.sanityChecks, 0, sanityChecks.length);
3059        }
3060        this.clean = clean;
3061        this.modifiers = new ArrayList<>(modifiers);
3062    }

3064    private static String[] processParts(OrderedMap<String, String> parts, Set<String> missingSounds,
3065                                         Set<String> forbidden, IRNG rng, double repeatSingleChance,
3066                                         int preferredLimit) {
3067        int l, sz = parts.size();
3068        List<String> working = new ArrayList<>(sz * 24);
3069        String pair;
3070        for (int e = 0; e < parts.size(); e++) {
3071            Map.Entry<String, String> sn = parts.entryAt(e);
3072            if (missingSounds.contains(sn.getKey()))
3073                continue;
3074            for (String t : sn.getValue().split(" ")) {
3075                if (forbidden.contains(t))
3076                    continue;
3077                l = t.length();
3078                int num;
3079                char c;
3080                switch (l) {
3081                    case 0:
3082                        break;
3083                    case 1:
3084                        working.add(t);
3085                        working.add(t);
3086                        working.add(t);
3087                        c = t.charAt(0);
3088                        num = 0;
3089                        boolean repeat = true;
3090                        switch (c) {
3091                            case 'w':
3092                                num += 2;
3093                            case 'y':
3094                            case 'h':
3095                                num += 4;
3096                            case 'q':
3097                            case 'x':
3098                                num += 4;
3099                                repeat = false;
3100                                break;
3101                            case 'i':
3102                            case 'u':
3103                                repeat = false;
3104                                num = 13;
3105                                break;
3106                            case 'z':
3107                            case 'v':
3108                                num = 4;
3109                                break;
3110                            case 'j':
3111                                num = 7;
3112                                break;
3113                            default:
3114                                if (e >= preferredLimit)
3115                                    num = 6;
3116                                else
3117                                    num = 13;
3118                        }
3119                        for (int i = 0; i < num * 3; i++) {
3120                            if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.75) {
3121                                working.add(t);
3122                            }
3123                        }
3124
3125                        if (repeat && rng.nextDouble() < repeatSingleChance) {
3126                            pair = t + t;
3127                            if (missingSounds.contains(pair))
3128                                continue;
3129                            working.add(pair);
3130                            working.add(pair);
3131                            working.add(pair);
3132                            if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.7) {
3133                                working.add(pair);
3134                                working.add(pair);
3135                            }
3136                            if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.7) {
3137                                working.add(pair);
3138                            }
3139                        }
3140
3141                        break;
3142                    case 2:
3143                        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.65) {
3144                            c = t.charAt(1);
3145                            num = 0;
3146                            switch (c) {
3147                                case 'z':
3148                                    num = 1;
3149                                    break;
3150                                case 'w':
3151                                    num = 3;
3152                                    break;
3153                                case 'n':
3154                                    num = 4;
3155                                    break;
3156                                default:
3157
3158                                    if (e >= preferredLimit)
3159                                        num = 2;
3160                                    else
3161                                        num = 7;
3162                            }
3163                            working.add(t);
3164                            for (int i = 0; i < num; i++) {
3165                                if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.25) {
3166                                    working.add(t);
3167                                }
3168                            }
3169                        }
3170                        break;
3171                    case 3:
3172                        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.5) {
3173                            c = t.charAt(0);
3174                            switch (c) {
3175                                case 'z':
3176                                    num = 1;
3177                                    break;
3178                                case 'w':
3179                                    num = 3;
3180                                    break;
3181                                case 'n':
3182                                    num = 4;
3183                                    break;
3184                                default:
3185                                    if (e >= preferredLimit)
3186                                        num = 2;
3187                                    else
3188                                        num = 6;
3189                            }
3190                            working.add(t);
3191                            for (int i = 0; i < num; i++) {
3192                                if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.2) {
3193                                    working.add(t);
3194                                }
3195                            }
3196                        }
3197                        break;
3198                    default:
3199                        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.3 && (t.charAt(l - 1) != 'z' || rng.nextDouble() < 0.1)) {
3200                            working.add(t);
3201                        }
3202                        break;
3203                }
3204            }
3205        }
3206        return working.toArray(new String[0]);
3207    }

3222    public static FakeLanguageGen randomLanguage(long seed) {
3223        GWTRNG rng = new GWTRNG(seed);
3224        int[] lengths = new int[rng.between(3, 5)];
3225        System.arraycopy(new int[]{1, 2, 3, 4}, 0, lengths, 0, lengths.length);
3226        double[] chances = new double[lengths.length];
3227        System.arraycopy(new double[]{
3228                5 + rng.nextDouble(4), 13 + rng.nextDouble(9), 3 + rng.nextDouble(3), 1 + rng.nextDouble(2)
3229        }, 0, chances, 0, chances.length);
3230        double vowelHeavy = rng.between(0.2, 0.5), removalRate = rng.between(0.15, 0.65);
3231        int sz = openCons.size();
3232        int[] reordering = rng.randomOrdering(sz), vOrd = rng.randomOrdering(openVowels.size());
3233        OrderedMap<String, String>
3234                parts0 = new OrderedMap<>(openVowels),
3235                parts1 = new OrderedMap<>(openCons),
3236                parts2 = new OrderedMap<>(midCons),
3237                parts3 = new OrderedMap<>(closeCons);
3238        OrderedSet<String> forbidden = new OrderedSet<>(1024, 0.25f), missingSounds = new OrderedSet<>(64, 0.875f);
3239        parts1.reorder(reordering);
3240        parts2.reorder(reordering);
3241        parts3.reorder(reordering);
3242        parts0.reorder(vOrd);
3243        int n = 0;
3244
3245        int mn = Math.min(rng.nextInt(3), rng.nextInt(3)), sz0, p0s;
3246
3247        for (n = 0; n < mn; n++) {
3248            missingSounds.add(parts0.keyAt(0));
3249            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts0.getAt(0).split(" "));
3250            parts0.removeFirst();
3251        }
3252        p0s = parts0.size();
3253        sz0 = Math.max(rng.between(1, p0s + 1), rng.between(1, p0s + 1));
3254        char[] nextAccents = new char[sz0], unaccented = new char[sz0];
3255        int vowelAccent = rng.between(1, 7);
3256        for (int i = 0; i < sz0; i++) {
3257            nextAccents[i] = accentedVowels[vOrd[i + mn]][vowelAccent];
3258            unaccented[i] = accentedVowels[vOrd[i + mn]][0];
3259        }
3260        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.8) {
3261            for (int i = 0; i < sz0; i++) {
3262                char ac = nextAccents[i], ua = unaccented[i];
3263                String v = "", uas = String.valueOf(ua);
3264                Pattern pat = Pattern.compile("\\b([aeiou]*)(" + ua + ")([aeiou]*)\\b");
3265                Replacer rep = pat.replacer("$1$2$3 $1" + ac + "$3"), repLess = pat.replacer("$1" + ac + "$3");
3266                for (int j = 0; j < p0s; j++) {
3267                    String k = parts0.keyAt(j);
3268                    if (uas.equals(k)) // uas is never null, always length 1
3269                        v = parts0.getAt(j);
3270                    else {
3271                        String current = parts0.getAt(j);
3272                        String[] splits = current.split(" ");
3273                        for (int s = 0; s < splits.length; s++) {
3274                            if (forbidden.contains(uas) && splits[s].contains(uas))
3275                                forbidden.add(splits[s].replace(ua, ac));
3276                        }
3277                        parts0.put(k, rep.replace(current));
3278                    }
3279                }
3280                parts0.put(String.valueOf(ac), repLess.replace(v));
3281            }
3282        }
3283
3284        n = 0;
3285        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.75) {
3286            missingSounds.add("z");
3287            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("z").split(" "));
3288            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("z").split(" "));
3289            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("z").split(" "));
3290            n++;
3291        }
3292        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.82) {
3293            missingSounds.add("x");
3294            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("x").split(" "));
3295            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("x").split(" "));
3296            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("x").split(" "));
3297            n++;
3298        }
3299        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.92) {
3300            missingSounds.add("qu");
3301            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("qu").split(" "));
3302            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("qu").split(" "));
3303            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("qu").split(" "));
3304            n++;
3305        }
3306        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.96) {
3307            missingSounds.add("q");
3308            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("q").split(" "));
3309            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("q").split(" "));
3310            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("q").split(" "));
3311            n++;
3312        }
3313        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.97) {
3314            missingSounds.add("tl");
3315            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("tl").split(" "));
3316            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("tl").split(" "));
3317            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("tl").split(" "));
3318            n++;
3319        }
3320        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.86) {
3321            missingSounds.add("ph");
3322            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("ph").split(" "));
3323            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("ph").split(" "));
3324            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("ph").split(" "));
3325            n++;
3326        }
3327        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.94) {
3328            missingSounds.add("kh");
3329            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("kh").split(" "));
3330            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("kh").split(" "));
3331            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("kh").split(" "));
3332            n++;
3333        }
3334        if (rng.nextDouble() < 0.96) {
3335            missingSounds.add("bh");
3336            missingSounds.add("dh");
3337            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("bh").split(" "));
3338            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("bh").split(" "));
3339            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("bh").split(" "));
3340            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.get("dh").split(" "));
3341            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.get("dh").split(" "));
3342            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.get("dh").split(" "));
3343            n++;
3344            n++;
3345        }
3346
3347        for (; n < sz * removalRate; n++) {
3348            missingSounds.add(parts1.keyAt(n));
3349            missingSounds.add(parts2.keyAt(n));
3350            missingSounds.add(parts3.keyAt(n));
3351            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts1.getAt(n).split(" "));
3352            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts2.getAt(n).split(" "));
3353            Collections.addAll(forbidden, parts3.getAt(n).split(" "));
3354        }
3355
3356        return new FakeLanguageGen(
3357                processParts(parts0, missingSounds, forbidden, rng, 0.0, p0s),
3358                new String[]{},
3359                processParts(openCons, missingSounds, forbidden, rng, 0.0, 4096),
3360                processParts(midCons, missingSounds, forbidden, rng, (rng.nextDouble() * 3 - 0.75) * 0.4444, 4096),
3361                processParts(closeCons, missingSounds, forbidden, rng, (rng.nextDouble() * 3 - 0.75) * 0.2857, 4096),
3362                new String[]{},
3363                new String[]{}, lengths, chances, vowelHeavy, vowelHeavy * 1.8, 0.0, 0.0, genericSanityChecks, true).summarize("0#" + seed + "@1");
3364    }

3366    protected static boolean checkAll(CharSequence testing, Pattern[] checks) {
3367        CharSequence fixed = removeAccents(testing);
3368        for (int i = 0; i < checks.length; i++) {
3369            if (checks[i].matcher(fixed).find())
3370                return false;
3371        }
3372        return true;
3373    }
3374
3375    /**
3376     * Checks a CharSequence, such as a String, against an overzealous vulgarity filter, returning true if the text
3377     * could contain vulgar elements or words that could seem vulgar or juvenile. The idea here is that false positives
3378     * are OK as long as there are very few false negatives (missed vulgar words). Does not check punctuation or numbers
3379     * that could look like letters.
3380     * @param testing the text, as a CharSequence such as a String, to check
3381     * @return true if the text could contain a vulgar or juvenile element; false if it probably doesn't
3382     */
3383    public static boolean checkVulgarity(CharSequence testing)
3384    {
3385        CharSequence fixed = removeAccents(testing);
3386        for (int i = 0; i < vulgarChecks.length; i++) {
3387            if (vulgarChecks[i].matcher(fixed).find())
3388            {
3389//                System.out.println(vulgarChecks[i]);
3390                return true;
3391            }
3392        }
3393        return false;
3394    }

3400     * @return a word in the fake language as a String
3401     */
3402    public String word(boolean capitalize) {
3403        return word(srng, capitalize);

3407     * Generate a word from this FakeLanguageGen using the specified long seed to use for a shared StatefulRNG.
3408     * If seed is the same, a FakeLanguageGen should produce the same word every time with this method.
3409     *
3410     * @param seed       the seed, as a long, to use for the randomized string building
3411     * @param capitalize true if the word should start with a capital letter, false otherwise
3412     * @return a word in the fake language as a String
3413     */
3414    public String word(long seed, boolean capitalize) {
3415        srng.setState(seed);
3416        return word(srng, capitalize);
3417    }
3418
3419    /**
3420     * Generate a word from this FakeLanguageGen using the specified RNG.
3421     *
3422     * @param rng        the RNG to use for the randomized string building
3423     * @param capitalize true if the word should start with a capital letter, false otherwise
3424     * @return a word in the fake language as a String
3425     */
3426    public String word(IRNG rng, boolean capitalize) {
3427        while (true) {
3428            sb.setLength(0);
3429            ender.setLength(0);
3430
3431            double syllableChance = rng.nextDouble(totalSyllableFrequency);
3432            int syllables = 1, i = 0;
3433            for (int s = 0; s < syllableFrequencies.length; s++) {
3434                if(syllableChance < syllableFrequencies[s])
3435                {
3436                    syllables = s + 1;
3437                    break;
3438                } else
3439                {
3440                    syllableChance -= syllableFrequencies[s];
3441                }
3442            }
3443            if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelStartFrequency) {
3444                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(openingVowels));
3445                if (syllables == 1)
3446                    sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(closingConsonants));
3447                else
3448                    sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(midConsonants));
3449                i++;
3450            } else {
3451                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(openingConsonants));
3452            }
3453            String close = "";
3454            boolean redouble = false;
3455            if (i < syllables) {
3456                if (rng.nextDouble() < syllableEndFrequency) {
3457                    close = rng.getRandomElement(closingSyllables);
3458                    if (close.contains("@") && (syllables & 1) == 0) {
3459                        redouble = true;
3460                        syllables >>= 1;
3461
3462                        //sb.append(close.replaceAll("@\\d", sb.toString()));
3463                    }
3464                    if (!close.contains("@"))
3465                        ender.append(close);
3466                    else if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelEndFrequency) {
3467                        ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3468                        if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelSplitFrequency) {
3469                            ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(vowelSplitters))
3470                                    .append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3471                        }
3472                    }
3473                } else {
3474                    ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3475                    if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelSplitFrequency) {
3476                        ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(vowelSplitters))
3477                                .append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3478                    }
3479                    if (rng.nextDouble() >= vowelEndFrequency) {
3480                        ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(closingConsonants));
3481                        if (rng.nextDouble() < syllableEndFrequency) {
3482                            close = rng.getRandomElement(closingSyllables);
3483                            if (close.contains("@") && (syllables & 1) == 0) {
3484                                redouble = true;
3485                                syllables >>= 1;
3486
3487                                //sb.append(close.replaceAll("@\\d", sb.toString()));
3488                            }
3489                            if (!close.contains("@"))
3490                                ender.append(close);
3491                        }
3492                    }
3493                }
3494                i += vowelClusters.matcher(ender).findAll().count();
3495
3496            }
3497
3498            for (; i < syllables; i++) {
3499                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3500                if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelSplitFrequency) {
3501                    sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(vowelSplitters))
3502                            .append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3503                }
3504                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(midConsonants));
3505            }
3506
3507            sb.append(ender);
3508            if (redouble && i <= syllables + 1) {
3509                sb.append(close.replaceAll("@", sb.toString()));
3510            }
3511
3512            if (sanityChecks != null && !checkAll(sb, sanityChecks))
3513            {
3514                continue;
3515            }
3516
3517            for (int m = 0; m < modifiers.size(); m++) {
3518                modifiers.get(m).modify(rng, sb);
3519            }
3520
3521            if (capitalize)
3522                sb.setCharAt(0, Character.toUpperCase(sb.charAt(0)));
3523
3524            if (clean && !checkAll(sb, vulgarChecks))
3525            {
3526                continue;
3527            }
3528            return sb.toString();
3529        }
3530    }

3542     */

3556    public String word(IRNG rng, boolean capitalize, int approxSyllables) {

3559    /**
3560     * Generate a word from this FakeLanguageGen with an approximate number of syllables using the specified long seed 
3561     * to use for a shared StatefulRNG. This takes an array of {@link Pattern} objects (from RegExodus, not
3562     * java.util.regex) that should match invalid outputs, such as words that shouldn't be generated in some context due
3563     * to vulgarity or cultural matters. If seed and the other parameters are the same, a FakeLanguageGen should produce
3564     * the same word every time with this method.
3565     *
3566     * @param seed       the seed, as a long, to use for the randomized string building
3567     * @param capitalize true if the word should start with a capital letter, false otherwise
3568     * @param approxSyllables the approximate number of syllables to produce in the word; there may be more syllables
3569     * @param additionalChecks an array of RegExodus Pattern objects that match invalid words (these may be additional vulgarity checks, for example)
3570     * @return a word in the fake language as a String
3571     */
3572    public String word(long seed, boolean capitalize, int approxSyllables, Pattern[] additionalChecks) {
3573        srng.setState(seed);
3574        return word(srng, capitalize, approxSyllables, additionalChecks);
3575    }
3576
3577    /**
3578     * Generate a word from this FakeLanguageGen using the specified RNG with an approximate number of syllables.
3579     * This takes an array of {@link Pattern} objects (from RegExodus, not java.util.regex) that should match invalid
3580     * outputs, such as words that shouldn't be generated in some context due to vulgarity or cultural matters.
3581     *
3582     * @param rng        the RNG to use for the randomized string building
3583     * @param capitalize true if the word should start with a capital letter, false otherwise
3584     * @param approxSyllables the approximate number of syllables to produce in the word; there may be more syllables
3585     * @param additionalChecks an array of RegExodus Pattern objects that match invalid words (these may be additional vulgarity checks, for example)
3586     * @return a word in the fake language as a String
3587     */
3588    public String word(IRNG rng, boolean capitalize, int approxSyllables, Pattern[] additionalChecks) {
3589        if (approxSyllables <= 0) {
3590            sb.setLength(0);
3591            sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(openingVowels));
3592            for (int m = 0; m < modifiers.size(); m++) {
3593                modifiers.get(m).modify(rng, sb);
3594            }
3595            if (capitalize) sb.setCharAt(0, Character.toUpperCase(sb.charAt(0)));
3596            return sb.toString();
3597        }
3598        while (true) {
3599            sb.setLength(0);
3600            ender.setLength(0);
3601            int i = 0;
3602            if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelStartFrequency) {
3603                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(openingVowels));
3604                if (approxSyllables == 1 && closingConsonants.length > 0)
3605                    sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(closingConsonants));
3606                else if (midConsonants.length > 0)
3607                    sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(midConsonants));
3608                i++;
3609            } else if (openingConsonants.length > 0) {
3610                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(openingConsonants));
3611            }
3612            String close = "";
3613            boolean redouble = false;
3614            if (i < approxSyllables) {
3615                if (closingSyllables.length > 0 && rng.nextDouble() < syllableEndFrequency) {
3616                    close = rng.getRandomElement(closingSyllables);
3617                    if (close.contains("@") && (approxSyllables & 1) == 0) {
3618                        redouble = true;
3619                        approxSyllables = approxSyllables >> 1;
3620
3621                        //sb.append(close.replaceAll("@\\d", sb.toString()));
3622                    }
3623                    if (!close.contains("@"))
3624                        ender.append(close);
3625                    else if (redouble && rng.nextDouble() < vowelEndFrequency) {
3626                        ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3627                        if (vowelSplitters.length > 0 && rng.nextDouble() < vowelSplitFrequency) {
3628                            ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(vowelSplitters))
3629                                    .append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3630                        }
3631                    }
3632                } else {
3633                    ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3634                    if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelSplitFrequency) {
3635                        ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(vowelSplitters))
3636                                .append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3637                    }
3638                    if (rng.nextDouble() >= vowelEndFrequency) {
3639                        ender.append(rng.getRandomElement(closingConsonants));
3640                        if (rng.nextDouble() < syllableEndFrequency) {
3641                            close = rng.getRandomElement(closingSyllables);
3642                            if (close.contains("@") && (approxSyllables & 1) == 0) {
3643                                redouble = true;
3644                                approxSyllables = approxSyllables >> 1;
3645
3646                                //sb.append(close.replaceAll("@\\d", sb.toString()));
3647                            }
3648                            if (!close.contains("@"))
3649                                ender.append(close);
3650                        }
3651                    }
3652                }
3653                i += vowelClusters.matcher(ender).findAll().count();
3654            }
3655
3656            for (; i < approxSyllables; i++) {
3657                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3658                if (rng.nextDouble() < vowelSplitFrequency) {
3659                    sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(vowelSplitters))
3660                            .append(rng.getRandomElement(midVowels));
3661                }
3662                sb.append(rng.getRandomElement(midConsonants));
3663            }
3664
3665            sb.append(ender);
3666            if (redouble && i <= approxSyllables + 1) {
3667                sb.append(close.replaceAll("@", sb.toString()));
3668            }
3669
3670            if (sanityChecks != null && !checkAll(sb, sanityChecks))
3671                continue;
3672
3673            for (int m = 0; m < modifiers.size(); m++) {
3674                modifiers.get(m).modify(rng, sb);
3675            }
3676
3677            if (clean && !checkAll(sb, vulgarChecks))
3678                continue;
3679
3680            if (additionalChecks != null && !checkAll(sb, additionalChecks))
3681                continue;
3682
3683            if (capitalize)
3684                sb.setCharAt(0, Character.toUpperCase(sb.charAt(0)));
3685
3686            return sb.toString();
3687        }
3688    }
